top_comment.text:
How would you go about clipping a dog's claws who absolutely hates having 
their paws touched? Unfortunately our dog isn't crazy about food or treats, 
he even passes up high quality wet food sometimes, so are there other items 
that you would recommend as a reward?﻿
top_comment.author: Erin Summer

comments.text:
+Erin Summer Massages. If you offer food and they don't take it, you lose 
their trust. You have to work with the dog as each dog is different, there 
isn't a magically way for all dogs.

Sounds like you have exactly the right dog for the actions suggested in 
this video. Go slowly, work your way to the paws, and make it an overall 
positive experience.

Find out what your dog loves. Most labs love water. Some dogs find play 
particularly rewarding. Some dogs really love certain foods. Like the video 
said, it's all about positive reinforcement, and making the experience good 
for the dog so that he associates nail-clipping with reward.

Most dogs love food and will take food, unless they are nervous or anxious. 
If you practiced a strict routine while raising your dog, and he exhibits 
food aggression and/or aloof behavior around food, something may be wrong.

Best of luck!
comments.author: Christopher Hitchens

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana He does only get a limited amount of food twice a 
day, morning and before bed, most of the time he doesn't finish it. Thank 
you for the reply.
comments.author: Erin Summer

comments.text:
Do you free freed your pup? He should be fed a limited amount twice a day. 
This might make him more excited about treats (just like snacks sound good 
to us a few hours after we've had a meal, but not so good after we've just 
eaten). If your dog really doesn't find food that rewarding, you can use 
interaction, play, and/or massage to reward accepting the nail clipping.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text: What should someone do if they find a baby bird in their yard?﻿
top_comment.author: Jacob Cooperstein

comments.text:
You should usually wait and see if the parents are around to reclaim the 
chick. If you've waited about an hour or so and there are no signs of a 
parent, you should take action. If there is a wildlife rehab center or 
animal rescue within reasonable distance, the best thing you can do is 
drive the chick to them. If there is not, you might be forced to either 
raise the chick yourself or humanely euthanize him/her. Different bird 
species have different needs, but most need to be hand fed at a young age. 
When I volunteered for the Wildlife Care Association in California, we used 
syringes filled with specific powdered food mixes to feed young chicks. If 
you don't have the specific food powder, you can improvise. If the chick is 
a songbird, mash some fruits into a paste, mix with some water (the younger 
the bird, the more water), and feed via a 1cc syringe. For columbiformes 
(pigeons and doves), you have to find a crop milk substitute. For corvids 
(crows, magpies, scrub jays, etc.), I actually don't have a good idea, but 
I've seen people use mashed cat food. When they're old enough, we let them 
eat solid food, sometimes even live meal worms. You could probably find a 
lot of information online than what I can give you.
comments.author: ShadeSlayer1911

comments.text: Thank you!!! :D
comments.author: Jacob Cooperstein

comments.text:
if you live neer a vet take it to them they usually will humanly euthanize 
it however it is usually for the best or possibly try contact a bird 
sanctuary
comments.author: Roisin Mullaney

comments.text:
+Jacob Cooperstein Just wash your hands with soap and for 20 seconds after 
you touch any wild animal. This will kill any bacteria that the baby bird 
might have on them.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

comments.text: Will I get sick if I touch it with my bare hands? Should I use gloves?
comments.author: Jacob Cooperstein

comments.text:
Firstly, don't be afraid to touch it. Mothers won't disown their chick just 
because it smells of human, just as (most) parents wouldn't abandon their 
child for not showering. If it is obviously injured and won't survive, kill 
it humanely (I know it sounds bad, but it's the best you can do). 
Otherwise, if it looks like it can handle itself, leave it where it is. 
When birds start learning to fly, accidental crashes are common. If you can 
tell where it's nest is, you could deposit it back there if you want.
comments.author: DigitalCoffeeBrewer

top_comment.text:
I've got a dog that's really old and has dealt with a lot of abuse in her 
past, including what I suspect were improperly handled clipping events. We 
haven't been able to clip her claws ourselves because she whimpers at the 
very sight of the clippers, so we've been forced to take her to the vet 
each time just so they don't get so long that her feet begin to hurt. Is 
there some possible way to help her become comfortable with this, or is it 
just one of those "you can't teach an old dog new tricks" things that we'll 
have to accept? It always breaks my heart to have to take her in, because 
it's like she knows what she's getting into, and she always seems miserable 
when she comes out of the vet's office afterwards. I'd love to find a way 
to make it at least less stressful for her.﻿
top_comment.author: IslidDavilas

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana Thank you so much! I'll be sure to work on that with 
her in the future. :)
comments.author: IslidDavilas

comments.text:
It's never too late to teach an animal something new. I would begin by 
finding out what her very favorite treat is. Then give her that treat only 
at specific times. I would introduce the clippers in a very non-threatening 
way, like lay them in your lap and call her over. Don't even point the 
clippers out, just give her a treat. Once she knows she's in for a treat 
session and she's happy about it, put the treat on your lap next to the 
clippers and that will be the starting point. Keep pairing the treat with 
the clippers. Slowly you can put the treat on the clippers, or move the 
clippers slightly, an eventually hold them in your hand. Take very small 
steps toward your goal.

Also make sure you're working toward touching her foot. Don't introduce the 
clippers during foot massage time. Once she's doing good with the clippers 
and foot touching, then you can bring them together. This is going to a be 
slow process, but even if it takes a month or two, reducing the stress she 
goes through is worth it. Good luck!
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text: So how do the nails stay short in the wild?﻿
top_comment.author: Jorgensen Penus

top_comment.text:
Perfect timing!  I was just talking to my boyfriend about how we really 
should sit down with our dog (Scout the American Eskimo) and clip his 
nails.  It's not the first time he's had his nails clipped, but it's the 
first time we've done it, since we recently adopted him from a rescue. 
 He's a little foot-sensitive, but I think petting him and giving him 
treats will help calm him down.  :)  Thank you, Jessi!﻿
top_comment.author: posthumorously

top_comment.text:
I notice that Molly has much lighter nails, my dog has black nails and we 
often have trouble cutting them without them bleeding, they have gotten 
kinda long.  What would you suggest?﻿
top_comment.author: Jessica Albee (JessBooks)

comments.text: Thank you!  That's very helpful
comments.author: Jessica Albee (JessBooks)

comments.text:
Dark nails are definitely more difficult. I would suggest using her paw pad 
to see where you should clip. The nail should not be past the bottom of the 
pad, so use that as your guide. Have the styptic powder ready. Take a 
little bit at a time and get more familiar with the shape of her nail. You 
can also tell where the quick stops by looking underneath and noticing 
where the nail become indented and almost hollow looking.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text: When you're done, remember to dispose of the clippings, not the dog.﻿
top_comment.author: Milewide

comments.text:
+higbey the demon Indeed, it's a common problem that ultimately leads to a 
shortage of dogs.
comments.author: Milewide

comments.text: so thats what I've been doing wrong.
comments.author: higbey the demon

top_comment.text:
We recently found a dog on the street, its nails are very neglected and 
long but the quick is also just about meeting the actual pad! i don't know 
how to really clip them short enough for a healthy paw, should i clip of 
use a buffer and saw away around the quiks?﻿
top_comment.author: xXSlaughter3dXx

comments.text: thank you
comments.author: xXSlaughter3dXx

comments.text:
When that happens, just clip a tiny bit at a time.  The quick will shorten 
with regular trimmings.
comments.author: historymeg83

top_comment.text: Cool video, but I think perhaps too much emphasis was placed on the food.﻿
top_comment.author: Christopher Hitchens

comments.text:
+WyrmsRoost I'm not sure how else I could phrase this. I just think too 
much food was used. See below for someone saying food had no effect on 
their dog, and see my response.
comments.author: Christopher Hitchens

comments.text: How come, what makes you say so?
comments.author: WyrmsRoost

top_comment.text:
My rescued Lilacine Amazon parrot is very afraid of getting his nails 
clipped and I've avoided it as much as possible but his nails are just too 
long now. Do you have and advice? Thanks:)﻿
top_comment.author: Eleanor J

comments.text:
Thanks so much for your advice, I really appreciate it. I've just done a 
quick search and it doesn't seem very common in the UK. I'll keep an eye 
out for some.
comments.author: Eleanor J

comments.text:
I likely misspelled that, but it is a soft wood usually used in crafting.  
Such as little airplanes, it works well for wheels and propellers, because 
of its ultra-fine cork like texture.  It is not rough but the sharp ends of 
the nail will sink it to the wood, likely blunting the claw.  Just an idea 
but the wood is expensive, so it might only cost a little more than 
expected but be cheaper that taking him to a vet each time.
comments.author: Alec Risser

comments.text:
Balsa wood? I don't think I've heard of that, he has a nail filing perch 
but it's not really doing anything. I'll definitely have a look for that! 
Thank you:)
comments.author: Eleanor J

comments.text:
Give him something like balsa wood to climb on, something that will catch 
and chip off the ends of his nails without breaking off the whole nail.
comments.author: Alec Risser

comments.text: That's great, thanks a lot!
comments.author: Eleanor J

comments.text:
I would bring your Amazon to the vet for a trim and then start working on 
making the clipper less scary. This will bide you a month or so to work on 
desensitizing him while his nails are slowly growing back. If his nails get 
too long, it can cause issues with his ability to perch naturally and they 
can get stuck on the cage bars and/or toys. I've rescued birds that have 
broken toes due to long nails getting caught on things.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text: how would this differ with a cat? ﻿
top_comment.author: Lucas Hamilton

comments.text:
Cats' claws retract, so you need to gently squeeze their paw to extend 
them. Otherwise, the positive reinforcement and stress reduction should be 
the same
comments.author: Emmasama240

comments.text:
Not too much different, it helps to start young, my rescue cat was never 
really raised with her paws touched, and was also declawed so touching her 
paws is so traumatic to her that we don't even clip (it's taken me years to 
get her to accept and enjoy brushing). But the two new kittens of my 
parent's it's just constantly making sure that it's never stressful when 
they're touched, massages and touching their feet, and always listening 
when they protest and never forcing them for the clipper. As someone else 
mentioned: you don't have to do every nail in one session.
comments.author: Nailkita

top_comment.text:
What kind of dogs need nail trimming? Or the need for it is based on 
lifestyle? ﻿
top_comment.author: 1234kalmar

comments.text: +AnimalWonders Montana Thank you! :3
comments.author: 1234kalmar

comments.text:
Dogs only need their nails trimmed if they don't wear them down on their 
own. Dogs that love to dig or that live on a hard surface will be more 
likely to naturally wear their nails during play. Dogs that live indoors 
all or most of the time will likely need regular trimmings to keep them at 
appropriate length. If nails get too long they can cause it to be 
uncomfortable to walk.

For example: Molly, the beagle in the video, loves to dig and only needs 
her nails trimmed in the winter when the ground is covered in several feet 
of snow.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text:
I'm wondering why you don't train the dog to give you it's paw, so you 
don't force your way down the leg but the dog can give you it's paw 
'voluntarily' ?﻿
top_comment.author: Bastian Colding

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana ah okay, it'd just seems more natural to ask for the 
paw if the dog already knows how to do that, and it's usually fairly easy 
to teach them :) The desensitisation seems like a nice step two to me
comments.author: Bastian Colding

comments.text:
I have taught Molly to present her paw when I ask :)
In this video I didn't ask her because I wanted to demonstrate what you can 
do to help your dog become desensitized to you touching and manipulating 
their paw. Massage is a great way to help a dog enjoy being touched all 
over. I'm working on a series of how to train with positive reinforcement, 
and the 'paw present' will definitely be featured!
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text:
i was wondering if you could make a video about dog training in general? 
because there are a lot of different methods and i'm very curious what 
methods you use!
(also this might be a stupid question, but do cats need their nails trimmed 
or is having a scratching post enough?)﻿
top_comment.author: Mar

comments.text: thank you!
comments.author: Mar

comments.text:
Training videos coming soon!

Cats and dogs (and all animals for that matter) only need their nails 
trimmed if they are not keeping them trim themselves. For example: Molly 
the beagle, loves to dig so she keeps her nails short during the summer 
months and only needs them trimmed during the winter when she doesn't dig 
and trim them herself.

A scratching post will allow the cat to perform their natural nail 
sharpening behavior, which is very beneficial for them. It does not trim 
their nails.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text:
What would you change about this procedure when clipping a rabbit's nails? 
Right now nail trims are extremely stressful for both my rabbit and me--I 
bundle her in a towel and go as fast as I can, but it's kind of traumatic.﻿
top_comment.author: middlemuse

comments.text:
Something to keep in mind: if you flip your rabbit over on zher back and 
rub zher tummy, ze will instanly relax. Try it!
comments.author: bagelanjeli

comments.text:
+AnimalWonders Montana Great advice - also keep in mind that you don't have 
to clip every nail in one session.  Try doing one, then waiting a few hours 
and doing another one.  Maybe even just one a day until it becomes an 
easier routine for her.
comments.author: C Lund

comments.text:
I would change the tactic from going as fast as you can, to making it as 
stress free as you can.

Can you handle your rabbit when it's not nail clipping time? If you can 
then I would have someone else do the holding or clipping. It's difficult 
to do both. Get your rabbit familiar with having her feet touched by doing 
it often, whenever you hold her. Offer her some banana whenever you touch 
her feet. Use the banana to reinforce when she stays calm.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

top_comment.text: Har har har, a very pawsitive experience.﻿
top_comment.author: shirankao69

comments.text: +Emily Formato I like dogs.
comments.author: Riley B

comments.text: All these dog puns? You guys are barking mad.
comments.author: Emily Formato

comments.text: That was a howler.
comments.author: Sinnessa

top_comment.text:
just a quick question about the treats, how much should you give them? 
somehow, i'm afraid i'm overfeeding my dog with treat..(he's a maltese)﻿
top_comment.author: testing2488

comments.text:
I'd also say, if you're ever doing any training with food with a dog, when 
you measure out their food for breakfast and dinner, just take a handful of 
that food (assuming it's dry food) and use that as treats. That way your 
dog will still eat the same amount you were going to give it in the day in 
the first place, just some of it will be treats as training, the rest will 
be dinner. :)

I hope that made sense!!! xD
comments.author: Alex C.M

comments.text:
Since your pup is pretty small, make the treats extra small, like the size 
of half a pea. Keep your sessions short any only use about 5 treats each 
time, you can do several sessions each day. If your dog loves his/her food 
you can even use the regular kibble as the reward.
comments.author: AnimalWonders Montana

captions.text:
Hey, guys. Today we're going to do how to
trim your dogs nails.

This is Molly. She's a beagle, and she's going
to be our helper today, showing off how to
trim those nails.

A lot of people get really nervous about it
because they're worried about that quick that

they're going to get — that they're going
to accidentally clip.

And the way that you're going to avoid that
is by doing routine trimmings, and, if you

look at their paw and those nails, those nails
should never go past the pad of their foot.

So you just want to make sure... and you can
see hers are pretty short.

So the nail clipper has to be rounded like
that. Do not use a regular human nail or toenail

clippers. It's going to be flat, it's going
to push down on their nail, and it's going

to splinter their nail. It's not going to
feel good for them, and they'll never want
to do it again.

So you want to get this rounded one, so it
kind of wraps around their nail and it puts

pressure on all the angles. So it's going
to collapse in and do a nice, neat trim.

Now, the next thing you want to have on hand
is this little product here. It's a quick

stop. You can use any styptic powder and you
can actually use corn starch if you're in

a pickle. But, um, this styptic powder is
going to clot if you accidentally do nick
their quick.

So what you'll do is you'll just tap some
right into the lid there, grab an healthy

pinch of it, take their nail and pinch around
that nail and hold on to it for 10 seconds.

And it's going to clot up and you can just
let it go, and the nail will be perfectly

fine. You don't need to panic about it; they
will be okay.

So that's what you need: rounded nail clippers,
styptic powder, and you're good to go.

What you're going to do, is you're not going
to force them, you're not going, like, to

hold them down and grab their foot and try
and force them to trim their nail. That's

going to cause a sensitivity and a lot of
anxiety around it.

So what the first thing you want to do is
grab some food, some treats for your dog that

they're interested in. And you want to get
a very small piece, make them very small,

and let them know what they're up for, you
know, "Ooh, this is gonna be really fun, yes,
we got treats going on."

So she knows the treat is what's at stake
right here. So she wants that treat, and so-
[to Molly] stay...

Show her the clipper, say, "Oh, nothing's
wrong with the clipper, you'll actually get
treats when you smell that clipper."

Now come over here, and, give a nice massage,
get them relaxed.

Just start touching her, just start touching
your dog all over, get them used to, "Oh,
this is gonna be a fun session here."

Work your way down towards her legs, pick
up a paw, and then let it go... Pick up the
paw again, and let it go.
Give a treat.

What we're working towards is desensitization
here. So, we're not going to just go right

for the paw and go, "Okay, this is what we're
doing." It's just part of everything else,
part of the interaction.

So, paw again, a little bit more manipulation
with that paw, and give a treat again. Again,

this is all supposed to be very positive with
them.

Alright, so we're gonna get this paw again
-- [to Molly] good girl- and we're going to

pair it with this, and give a treat. [to Molly]
And come closer. C'mere. Good girl.

Okay, paw again, clippers, treat. You can
see her behavior: she knows what the two together

means. So you can she her face moving away,
she's kind of avoiding.

So I'm just going to continue to make it a
positive experience for her by lots of treats,

lots of massages, and now we're going to go
in for the actual clip. [To Molly] You're
looking for more treats?

Alright, so here's the clipper, I know, touch
touch. Tap a little bit. Make some noise.

Again with the treats- here. Good girl. Good
girl.

One more little tap. And I'm not gonna actually
clip her nail because it's very short, it's

good, but you would do a little bit of pressure
right there. Tiny bit.

Give them a jackpot which is a lot of treats,
kind of a little handful. And look at that

she offered me her paw back cuz she knows
the paw means more treats.

Yes? Oh it does mean clipper, too, though.
No, you won't give me your paw again? She's
like maybe I changed my mind there.

Now, you don't need to force, again, we talked
about we're not going to force this behavior

on her. It's not essential that you clip their
nails every single day. So work towards it.
Make it a positive experience.

Right now we're just going to do a full body
massage after to really reinforce that this

little session we just had was really fun.
And she'll start associating it and looking
forward to it the next time.

What do you think, Molly? You a good girl?
I have some more treats for you. What do you
think? You can get them. You can get them.

All right, guys. I hope you learned something
today. If you have any questions or comments

or concerns you can put them in the comments
below. You can also find me on Twitter, Tumblr,

and Facebook. And I hope you enjoyed our how
to session for this week.
